title: chore: clean up a few things around the script element check
body:
* Rename the flag to `allow_self_closing_script`, which may be verbose, but it's also not recommended to use anyway. And it feels a bit more descriptive, we don't ignore script errors, but allow the error of a self-closing script tag.
* Ensure that the configuration from the config file as well as from the CLI gets evaluated.
* Introduce an "options" struct, making future enhancements a bit simpler.
* Use plain strings for errors, vs concatenating and formatting.

@airblast-dev Maybe you want to double check. Most notably, any script element (not only trunk ones) seem to cause the issue. So I warn/error about all of them.

title: feat: allow better control over minification, default to off
body: closes https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/774

title: small fix to installation instructions
body:
`cargo install trunk --locked`
is written as 
`cargo install --locked`

this pull request fixes the issue

title: feat: raise error for self closing script tags.
body:
This adds a warning for when a self closing script tag is found.

Related Issue: https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/742

The exact message could be changed to whatever you prefer, but I do think that linking the discussion is a good idea instead of stacking a ton of information in the warn message.

Makes use of [`Element::is_self_closing`](https://docs.rs/lol_html/latest/lol_html/html_content/struct.Element.html#method.is_self_closing) to detect if the tag is self closed. This checks if the "/" character is in the end of the opening tag, not if the tag could have one. 

![image](https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/assets/111659262/98b75625-4608-4fee-9558-63399936cf99)

Edit: We can also add a general check in the Document initializer, that would check the script tags, and/or anything else.

title: docs: remove redundant text in homepage
Remove old nix unstable note from site
body: Removes outdated note from the site about trunk only being in the unstable nix channels as it is currently [in 23.11](https://search.nixos.org/packages?channel=23.11&show=trunk&type=packages)

title: chore: add version tests, and fix ci
body: Add some tests to validate version enforcement. Also fix the CI, as it looks like `0.19.0-alpha.1` is not intended to match other pre-release versions.

title: Use base64 standard alphabet for integrity hashes (closes #765)
refactor: extract html rewriting into its own module
refactor: remove workaround for !Send types in HTML pipeline.
body: Since we removed `nipper`, the workaround for `!Send` types isn't needed anymore when spawning a task.

title: fix: replace console.debug with console.log in initializer example.
body:
Some chromium based browsers require that "Verbose" logging is enabled to view outputs from `console.debug`. 

Since the intention is to display what can be done with a custom initializer, I think using `console.log` would be more suitable, and practical for people just trying out `trunk`. 

See issue: https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/754

title: Add ! to if statment fixing the logic
body: Fixes the example logic for initializer

title: chore: Remove `http-body` crate from dependencies
body:
`trunk` doesn't use http-body crate.  
I think `trunk` should remove `http-body` rather than update it.

title: fix: make manually inserted script tag, spec compliant.
body:
According to the [HTML spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/scripting.html) for the script tag "Neither tag is omissible." this means we must use opening and closing tags. While using `nipper` this mistake was silently corrected, so this is only coming up now. 

The behaviour of `lol_html`'s rewriter, is HTML spec compliant. Script tags that are inserted after an element without a closing tag, are not detected by `lol_html`. Meaning any modifications that are made, don't actually get applied.

All of the examples in the repository are spec compliant with the HTML script tag, however the example script tags in [trunk.rs](https://trunkrs.dev/assets/#script-assets) are considered invalid by `lol_html`, and incorrect by the HTML spec. The script tags on the site should also be corrected.

This fixes the issues mentioned in: https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/742#issuecomment-2016316971

title: perf: Remove unnecessary clone on target_html when minification isn't being performed.
body:
Removes an unnecessary clone on the HTML content, whilst minification isn't being performed.

The clone was not needed when `nipper` was still being used, but it became much more obvious when it was replaced by `lol_html`.

title: build: deny the use of expect
refactor: Replace the nipper dependency with lol_html.
body:
Replaces the non-maintained [nipper](https://github.com/importcjj/nipper) dependency, with [lol_html](https://github.com/cloudflare/lol-html).

The `nipper::Document` struct that was used in various parts of the application is now replaced with Trunk's own `Document` struct, that has various ease of use methods to mask the `lol_html::HtmlRewriter` and its caveats. 

## Fixes:
 - https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/742
 - Possibly a few other stuff mentioned in `nipper`'s [issues](https://github.com/importcjj/nipper/issues).

Any of the tests mentioned are run locally on my Ryzen 5 5600 CPU, so take the performance results with a grain of salt.

## Compile time:
`lol_html` taking longer to compile was consistent across multiple runs.
| Used dependency | duration |
|--------|--------|
| lol_html | 3m 12s |
| nipper | 3m 08s | 

## Runtime:
Tested on `yew-tailwindcss`, `no-rust`, and `yew` examples.
Results were within margin of error, both were pretty much the same.
Might do more runtime testing later.

## Notes:  
I believe the change will be better in the long term, as issues due to `nipper` might keep popping up in the long run.
That being said, the replacement `html_lol` does have some down sides. It is heavily intended for streaming HTML, and not reading a String directly, which causes the API to be a bit weird for our use case. I think this could be turned into an performance advantage with various changes to Trunk in the future. For now, the goal is to just replace `nipper`.

title: Embed sass source-maps in non-release builds
body:
Embedding sass source-maps in non-release builds would significantly improve development experience. This solves #528.

No extra files will be generated https://sass-lang.com/documentation/cli/dart-sass/#embed-source-map

title: Update Trunk.toml
body: proxy configuration no_system_prox should be no_system_proxy

title: Fix --enable-cooldown option not working
body:
Currently if I use `trunk serve --enable-cooldown` it doesn't trigger any build.
This PR fixes the `Instant`s being subtracted in the wrong order when using `--enable-cooldown` flag.

Also helps with #735

chore: fix warnings on win32
Add data-target-path to the remaining steps
Add data-target-path to more steps of the pipeline
feat: add data-target-path to the copy-file action
docs: Replace outdated web framework recommendation

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

body:
The [trunkrs.dev](https://trunkrs.dev/#app-setup) site currently recommends Seed as one of the “most popular [Rust web frameworks] today”, but Seed appears to no longer be actively developed or maintained.

This change keeps Yew as a suggested framework, adds ~Dioxus~ Leptos, and also links to an actively-maintained list of Rust libraries for building web pages.

title: feat: allow more control over the different base URLs
fix: handle initializer relative to html_dir
feat: add required trunk version, and update version check
body:
This PR makes trunk aware of its version. Enabling two features with that:

1. Allow enforcing a trunk version for a project. This allows one to require a certain trunk version for a project, e.g. in the case user newer features from trunk.
2. Implement an "update check", so that trunk can let you know that there's a newer version available.

The update check can be disabled by disabling the feature `update_check`. This might be useful for packagers, like nix and homebrew.

Replaces: #654

This is just a PoC. But so far it checks out. The idea is to allow tracking loading of the initial WASM blob, and maybe showing some graphical progress.

Feedback is welcome!

Using the hashed name will lead to a lot of intermediate files which need cleanup. Without really serving much purpose, as the files will never be re-used.

Closes: https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/659

title: Update minify-html and minify-js
body:
Fixes build issues related to https://github.com/wilsonzlin/minify-html/issues/166. In particular, building trunk was failing completely under Nix, which disallows internet access during builds.

Technically would have been solved just by updating minify-html, but the two packages are from the same author. So whatever, why not.

title: fix: await all asset pipeline, even if some fail

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
When a pipeline step fails, the while loop will fail fast, but this will leave all other tasks still running in the background. Which might lead to the case where longer running tasks (like cargo build) run, while others abort the build.

Having a case like this, might also lead to multiple cargo builds stacking up in the background.

It also might lead to the case where a failure, due to a missing directory, will repeated, as repeated builds are triggered by the initial cargo build. Because only after the initial cargo build, the target folder will be ignored. But as the build fails fast, a new build will be triggered, as changes to the target folder are not yet ignored.

Closes: https://github.com/trunk-rs/trunk/issues/662

title: fix: persist headers on ws handshake
body:
Currently when using the WebSocket Proxy, headers are not sent to the outbound request that
performs the upgrade request/handshake.

Here headers from incoming request are mapped to the outbound request to allow for
authentication.

In order to open to TLS/SSL connections the feature: `rustls-tls-webpki-roots` is also
enabled.

title: chore: update lockfile
chore: update cargo lock files
fix: calculate SRI for WASM file after running wasm-opt

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
In case wasm-opt is enabled (by default it is not) the SRI digest must be built from the final WASM file, after running wasm-opt. Otherwise the digest won't match.

Closes: #660

title: feat: improve error message for tool version error
body:
In case of using --offline, and requiring a specific version of a tool, the error just says "not found". However, it would be more helpful to indicate that the tool was found, but was of the wrong version ("version mismatch").

Closes: #650

title: fix: ignore failures during minification
body: If minification fails, then simply use the original content.

See #651

This should allow us to disable CSS minification for problematic files until a better solution is found.

labels.description: Something isn't working

title: refactor: pull out some code, turn struct into enum
fix: handle projects which have both a bin and lib (cdylib) target
body:
In a previous change `cdylib` targets have been added to the list of allowed artifacts. However, projects which are both a binary as well as a library, the compilation failed now, since both target artifacts (bin and lib) got added to the target output. It was not possible to select by name.

This change adds the `data-target-name` attribute to specifically select a target "by name", without having to use the `--bin` argument in cargo.

Closes: #630

title: fix: Use "global" mode for classic scripts
body:
When minifying JS, use the "global" mode for classic scripts and "module" for `type="module"`.

Closes: #629

title: feat: allow disabling SRI and minification
body: Both features seem to cause issues for some people. And while it's a good thing to have them by default, there should be a way out if they cause trouble. Or are not desired.

title: chore: switch back to rustls
body:
Using native-tls for serve components is tricky/not possible. Having native OS for the client side of things might be nice, but having two TLS stacks in a single application doesn't feel good either.

Removing native-tls drops a number of dependencies, which might be a good thing too.

title: Bring back trunk-ng into trunk
body:
This PR brings back the changes from `trunk-ng` into `trunk`.

There are a few non-technical changes in there too:

* Drop the manual changelog for an auto-generated on using conventional commits
* Drop the PR template (just let people bring what they think is best)
* Drop the auto-close GitHub PR/issues bot (I think it's a bad idea to just close user contributed feedback due to the lack of activity from the project)
* Drop the custom rustfmt file (stick to defaults)
* Drop the blog (last updated 2021)

Also, those changes come in with all their commits, un-squashed. I know this is a lot of personal taste. However, I believe that having the full history of a PR makes some sense. Maybe ask on the PR to squash certain commits. But then again, let's make it easy for people to contribute.

title: Fix version matching for sass compiled with dart2js

labels.name: disposition:merge
labels.description: The tagged item should probably be merged

body:
sass may report the version differently if it's the nodejs version of dart-sass:

```sh
$ sass --version
1.62.1 compiled with dart2js 2.19.6
```

I would expect the version to be `1.62.1`, but currently trunk thinks it's `1.62.1 compiled with dart2js 2.19.6`.

title: Add action/stale for repo cleanup
Extend the recent work to solidify the FS watcher

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

body:
Ultimately, deeper investigation has revealed that std::fs::copy will generate modification events on the source file (the file being copied) on some platforms. This has proven to be a source of difficulty for the FS watcher, and has lead to infinite build loops, despite the fact that none of the files / directories being watched were actually changed.

Here we implement a post-build cooldown interval of 1s. This ensures that in very fast builds, we do not end up receiving a modification event due to std::fs::copy (from the copy source).

Moreover, any FS events which have accumulated during the 1s cooldown will be purged. Altogether this will hopefully fully address the recursive build issue, and will hopefully not disrupt the development workflow.

**Related Issues**
- closes https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/issues/588
- extends https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/pull/569
- closes https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/issues/461
- closes https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/issues/422
- closes https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/pull/516
- closes https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/pull/459

**Checklist**
- [x] Updated CHANGELOG.md describing pertinent changes.
- [x] Updated README.md with pertinent info (may not always apply).

title: Bump the default tool versions
body:
Update a few Trunk deps.

Update the default tool versions.

Update deps of all example projects.

All extra paths per app archive are now optional. This allows for tool
applications to change extra artifacts without completely breaking
Trunk's build process, specifically the tool download & prep phase. In
such cases, we log a warning about the issue.

We should go ahead and fetch the latest artifacts from github by first
checking the releases/latest redirect, and then downloading the
corresponding version. This will only be performed when no tools are
present of the specific type. Running `trunk clean --tools` will clean
this cache of tools to allow downloading the latest (which is already
supported).

title: Test `CopyDir` and assert whether `data-target-path` is used
body:
Test `CopyDir` pipeline and assert whether `data-target-path` is used correctly when specified.

I had the same issue as #524, and while I figured it was stemming from a regression, I just realized it was because my trunk install was from before [`fbb0be`](https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/commit/fbb0be88d3b74a720a3c51380662fc46f19eab97) had landed and the `data-target-path` attr was simply ignored.

Regardless, I figured it would help to test if it was actually being used as intended so I loosely copied `copy_file_test.rs` to also test if dirs were created and contents copied.

Also do any of these points apply? It's just a test case after all.

title: Fixed Feature selection not working #462

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: This item needs some discussion

body:
fixed #462 

Feature flags being passed to trunk build (e.g. trunk build --features "myfeature") were not being passed on to cargo build. It was using the features in the attributes in the index.html file instead.

I've changed it to use those attributes if there are any and then fall back to the cli features. Happy to make this work the other way around.

title: Add some additional tests
Update CI to no longer deny linter warnings
body:
This can be a bit of a difficulty for folks opening PRs and then the linter complains about completely unrelated code and denies their PR.

Instead, we continue to warn about these issues, but we do not block CI.

title: Bump all deps to solve security advisories
body:
<!--
Thank you for taking the time to open a pull request!
Please review the checklist below and perform each of
the applicable tasks. ❤️!
-->
**Checklist**
- [x] Updated CHANGELOG.md describing pertinent changes.
- [x] Updated README.md with pertinent info (may not always apply).
- [x] Updated `site` content with pertinent info (may not always apply).
- [x] Squash down commits to one or two logical commits which clearly describe the work you've done. If you don't, then Dodd will 🤓.

We currently have a few open security advisories, most prominently the use of `wee_alloc`. None of the advisories are actually targeted towards the main `trunk` binary, but instead in the examples. Still good to bump trunks deps as well, to stay up to date.

All examples are a bit old in regards to dependencies, so all were bumped to the latest, and I unified the version scheme used (was a mix of `0.1.1` vs `0.1` and `1.0.0` vs `1` and so on). Personally prefer to use the full version requirement, but we already use the short versions in trunk itself, so its all consistent.

Only thing that's outstanding is the bump from **yew** v0.18 to v0.19. The `yew-tailwindcss` example can probably be updated easily, but I prefer to do that as separate PR. For the `yew` example, we might consider removing `ybc` in favor of a non-framework implementation, as it's not actively developed anymore?

### Further notes

It seems the `notify` v5 is finally out, and has moved debouncing logic into a separate crate. I didn't update it as part of this PR, as we had lots of forth and back with that crate in the past. Probably best to do extensive testing when we update this, as it can cause quite some potential trouble.

The v4 to v5 docs recommend also, that it's best for the app to check a file's content when receiving an update, so we might just combine that with other ideas of avoiding re-compilation of code on each event.

title: Pass attrs through on script tags
body:
<!--
Thank you for taking the time to open a pull request!
Please review the checklist below and perform each of
the applicable tasks. ❤️!
-->
**Checklist**
- [x] Updated CHANGELOG.md describing pertinent changes.
- [ ] Updated README.md with pertinent info (may not always apply).
- [ ] Updated `site` content with pertinent info (may not always apply).
- [X] Squash down commits to one or two logical commits which clearly describe the work you've done. If you don't, then Dodd will 🤓.

---

I didn't update the CHANGELOG, as the script functionality hasn't been released and I don't believe this is worth adding. If you disagree, let me know and I can update it. :)

This solves #429, where an input index.html that contains:
```html
<script data-trunk data-manual async defer src="assets/prism.js"></script>
```

will now be saved in the output index.html as:
```html
<script data-manual="" defer="" async="" src="/prism-f9cf5f0b49dcc1e.js"></script>
```

It appears that whatever is outputting the HTML automatically adds the `=""`, even when there was no value originally, but that's okay because it's still valid.

In `attrs_to_string`, I was originally outputting just the key when the value was empty, but `=""` was still being added, so I shortened the function by outputting `=""` anyways.

I wanted something like this for sharing an assets folder between multiple projects that each only need a subset of the assets. 

I considered `data-keep-prefix` instead, but this is more flexible and felt simpler to implement.

I'm open to name bikeshedding or another way to achieve the same thing. It might also make sense to add the same functionality to `copy-file`.

title: Download native tooling for M1 (arm) MacOS
body:
First let me say that Trunk is really cool! The config-via-html mechanism is particularly elegant, nice job!

It seems that https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/pull/275 deliberately broke downloading for architectures besides x86_64, requiring those folks to manually download and install Sass, WasmBindgen, and WasmOpt. (Docs aren't clear on this either, hence https://github.com/thedodd/trunk/pull/375)

However, since WasmOpt and Sass have ARM builds and MacOS has an x86 emulation layer (Rosetta) that'll run WasmBindgen, we can actually support automatic tool downloads for M1 Macs no problem.

I refactored the existing URL-construction code so that it'll (hopefully) read more clearly and isolate the "logic" of URL construction in one place rather than across three methods (`target_os`, `target_arch`, and `url`).

I've tested this on an M1 Mac with a project and verifyed that Trunk downloads Sass, WasmBindgen, and WasmOpt to `~/Library/Caches/dev.trunkrs.trunk` and can run all of 'em successfully.

I haven't yet tested on x86 Mac or any Windows or Linux --- please let me know if that's something I'll need to figure out or if that's easier done in CI or by other folks. Thanks!


**Checklist**
- [x] Updated CHANGELOG.md describing pertinent changes.
- [n/a] Updated README.md with pertinent info (may not always apply).
- [n/a] Updated `site` content with pertinent info (may not always apply).
- [x] Squash down commits to one or two logical commits which clearly describe the work you've done. If you don't, then Dodd will 🤓.
